file_content.text: Our influence in the Tion Hegemony will continue to grow until we dominate the region.
The Tion Hegemony has sent an official message of gratitude for eliminating Doctor Lorrick. They seem quite eager to curry our favor.
Apparently, crushing our rivals sends an appropriate message to the rest of the galaxy. I only wish we could have recovered Lorrick's research.
A weaponized version of the rakghoul virus would have been a welcome addition to our arsenal.
The Emperor already has me to eliminate those who dare to oppose him. You would do well to remember that.
Welcome, but unnecessary.
I will not forget, my lord.
The virus is nothing when compared to the power of the dark side.
We have no need of it.
Of course, my lord. That alone should be enough to secure our position.
Not sure I really want the Empire to have that kind of technology.
Kind of glad it's gone.
I suppose I can understand your reluctance. In any case, the mission was still a success.
A weapon like that encourages others to come after us. Either to destroy it, or claim it themselves.
And a tempting target.
True enough, I suppose. Though I doubt anyone will move against us anytime soon.
When word gets out of what we've done, others will assume we acquired it. That could also be useful.
Nobody knows we don't have it.
Everyone's going to assume I got my hands on the virus when I took Lorrick out. You can use that.
Nobody knows we don't have it.
True. The mere threat of another outbreak is itself a weapon. Though I doubt we will need it anytime soon.
Do you disapprove of how I handled this mission?
Is that a complaint?
Forgive me, my lord. My words were just idle speculation. Your mission was a great success.
You got a problem with how the mission turned out?
Is that a complaint?
Not at all. Despite the failure to claim the virus, the mission was a great success.
We've eliminated a potential usurper of our power and strengthened ties with the Tion Hegemony.
This was a great victory for the Empire. The Republic will tremble in fear when they learn of this.
It will be a glorious day when our ancient enemy is finally wiped out.
Their days are numbered.
A day that draws closer, thanks to your actions.
I always try to leave my clients satisfied.
Glad I could help out.
The Republic is vulnerable, but they are far from defeated.
Don't underestimate them.
But we have the upper hand, and your actions have only increased our advantage. Their destruction is inevitable.
My work here is done.
Farewell. I look forward to working together again, should the opportunity arise.
We need to strike at Lorrick now, while he still thinks his identity is hidden!
Lorrick has many admirable qualities. He's intelligent, cunning and totally ruthless.
A decade ago, he was declared a traitor. He fled the Tion Hegemony and went into hiding on Ord Mantell.
He could be a valuable ally. Maybe we can use him as a weapon against the Republic.
We should recruit him.
He'd betray us at the first opportunity. He's a megalomaniac; convinced his destiny is to rule the entire galaxy.
If the Senate finds out what he's up to, they may send their own people in.
Does the Republic know of him?
Not to worry. As usual, the Republic is blind. They have no idea of the threat Lorrick represents.
He's spent the last ten years plotting a way to get even. Obsessive, but impressive.
Planning his revenge.
We suspect his ambitions go beyond the Tion Hegemony. He hungers for total galactic dominance.
Kaon and the other worlds were just a test, a way for Lorrick to study the effects of the modified rakghoul virus he developed.
If we can get our hands on this version of the plague, it could be a devastating weapon.
The virus could be useful.
The Republic is on its last legs. Lorrick's virus could provide the final blow to our enemy.
We had no idea he was working on this. The attack on Kaon tipped us off.
Exposing his plan was stupid.
A stroke of fortune we must capitalize on.
Lorrick isn't just going to sit around and wait for us to make the next move.
We have to act fast.
Reports of what happened on Kaon have been suppressed. Lorrick still thinks his identity is hidden. We have the element of surprise.
His guard may be down, but I still expect stiff resistance. This is going to get bloody. Very bloody.
He won't be defenseless.
I can think of no one else more suited for the task.
In addition to eliminating a potential rival, killing Lorrick should secure the allegiance of the Tion Hegemony.
Two birds with one stone.
At the very least it will keep them from looking to the Republic in the near future.
The Empire better appreciate what I'm bringing to the table. The Tion Hegemony's going to be in your back pocket after this.
Should be quite the payoff.
Don't worry. The Empire is known for two things: crushing our enemies, and rewarding our allies.
How do we proceed?
No point in being cunning when brute force will get the job done.
So let's use it.
The shuttle is waiting to take you to Doctor Lorrick's base on Ord Mantell.
Hopefully you'll find records of his experiments with the virus. That way, you won't have to take him alive.
Your work on Kaon was impressive.Your reputation is well earned.
With the source of the plague identified, the Tion royal family has been able to contain the outbreak.
It's unfortunate we couldn't question that pilot before you killed her. But we were still able to put together a file on Doctor Lorrick.
Do I need to remind you of your proper place, Darth Nurin?
You dare question my actions?
Forgive me, my lord. I meant no disrespect. I was merely making an observation.
The pilot had served her purpose. Leaving her alive only opened us up to possible betrayal.
She was no longer useful.
Of course, my lord. I hadn't thought of that. I should have known better than to question your judgment.
If you don't like how I do things, go hire someone else.
Is that a complaint?
That was merely an observation, not a critique. I am well satisfied with your performance so far.
Anything else she could have told us would have been lies or irrelevant. I saw no reason to waste your time.
I got what we needed.
Well, then, I commend you on your efficiency.
You bested the rakghouls on Kaon. I've no doubt you will do the same when you meet Lorrick in person.
We can't underestimate him.
However, they are too timid to move against Doctor Lorrick while he's on a Republic world.
What's happening with Melarra?
What about that pilot I found?
We tested her for the rakghoul virus. The results came back clean, so she was released.
The interrogators said she was most cooperative. Once she'd given them all the relevant information, they released her.
We honored the deal you struck with her. She was dropped off on a nearby world.
The pilot served her role by exposing Doctor Lorrick's involvement. Now it's up to us to eliminate him.
Pathetic. Guess it's up to us.
Agreed. Left unchecked, he could become a serious rival.
Tell me everything you've learned about Doctor Lorrick.
What do we know about him?
Major Byzal will make contact once you land on Kaon.
Welcome, my lord. I've been monitoring the situation in the Tion Hegemony. Things are getting worse.
Good. You're here. I've been monitoring the situation in the Tion Hegemony. Things are getting worse.
The Tion noble families have quarantined all worlds in the sector--no ships can land or leave without permission.
The announcement was not popular. Those trapped on the infected worlds feel betrayed by their rulers.
The nobles had to contain the outbreak using any means possible.
The quarantine was necessary.
I agree, though they should have acted sooner. They waited too long to impose travel restrictions, and the virus spread.
The chaos and confusion can be turned to our advantage.
We can exploit this.
Precisely. And I know the perfect place to strike.
What else have you learned?
Four worlds have been completely overrun. A fifth, Kaon, is down to a handful of survivors battling for their lives.
Among those survivors are several nobles related to the ruling family. But we will have to act quickly if we want to rescue them.
Why should we help those too weak to help themselves?
They do not deserve salvation.
Having allies in the ruling class could prove valuable in the future.
No doubt they'll be grateful.
I knew you would grasp the full implications of this situation, my lord.
You're paying the bills.
A hunt is a hunt.
The survivors may know something about the plague's origins. It's our best chance to learn who is behind this.
The only reason you'd want to save them is if they had valuable information.
You think they know something?
Your mind is quick. The survivors may help us discover who was behind the sudden outbreak of the plague.
Do we have permission to land on Kaon?
What about the quarantine?
We do. The nobles are desperate. They believe the plague was unleashed as an act of terrorism.
They see us as an ally against an unknown foe trying to destabilize the Tion Hegemony and seize power.
No rakghoul scares me.
The rakghouls are not the real enemy. They are only a tool; a weapon for a hidden foe.
Whoever unleashed this plague is trying to destabilize the Tion Hegemony so they can swoop in and seize power.
Someone with that kind of ambition could become a dangerous rival if left unchecked.
Once we find out who is behind this, I will destroy them.
The Emperor hates rivals.
Once we know who is responsible, we may be able to win them over to our side.
Maybe we can recruit them.
I just need a name.
I'll take them out.
Investigating the outbreak is our best hope of learning our enemy's true identity.
Turning the rakghoul plague into an instrument of war is an impressive feat.
They weaponized the virus?
Learning how the virus was synthesized could give us a powerful weapon to use against our foes.
So how do we stop them?
We have a contact on Kaon: Major Byzal, head of local security. He's cleared a shuttle to take you down to the surface.
Major Byzal will contact you with a situation update after you land.
